title: 107_hr874
content:
The Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001, also known as the "Act," makes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It specifies that no amendment in the Act will be considered a change in tax rates under section 15 of the Code. Additionally, the Act reduces marginal income tax rates for married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses for the year 2002. The tax rates based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess over $166,450
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. The tax rates for heads of households are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess. For unmarried individuals, the tax rates are as follows:
- Not over $10,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $10,000 but not over $36,250: $1,400 plus 15% of the excess
- Over $36,250 but not over $93,600: $5,337.50 plus 27% of the excess
- Over $93,600 but not over $151,600: $20,822 plus 30% of the excess
- Over $151,600 but not over $297,300: $38,222 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $297,300: $89,217 plus 38% of the excess. For unmarried individuals, the tax rates are as follows:
- Not over $10,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $10,000 but not over $36,250: $1,400 plus 15% of the excess
- Over $36,250 but not over $93,600: $5,337.50 plus 27% of the excess
- Over $93,600 but not over $151,600: $20,822 plus 30% of the excess
- Over $151,600 but not over $297,300: $38,222 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $297,300: $89,217 plus 38% of the excess. If taxable income is:
- Not over $6,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $6,000 but not over $27,050: $840 plus 15% of excess
- Over $27,050 but not over $65,550: $3,997.50 plus 27% of excess
- Over $65,550 but not over $136,750: $14,362.50 plus 30% of excess
- Over $136,750 but not over $297,300: $35,752.50 plus 35% of excess
- Over $297,300: $91,945 plus 38% of excess. Married individuals filing separate returns are subject to these tax rates. For married individuals filing separate returns, a tax is imposed on taxable income based on the following table: Not over $6,000: 14% of taxable income, Over $6,000 but not over $27,050: $840 plus 15% of excess, Over $27,050 but not over $65,550: $3,997.50 plus 27% of excess, Over $65,550 but not over $136,750: $14,362.50 plus 30% of excess, Over $136,750 but not over $297,300: $35,752.50 plus 35% of excess, Over $297,300: $91,945 plus 38% of excess. The tax rates for taxable income for married individuals filing separate returns are as follows: Not over $6,000: 14%, Over $6,000 but not over $27,050: $840 plus 15%, Over $27,050 but not over $65,550: $3,997.50 plus 27%, Over $65,550 but not over $136,750: $14,362.50 plus 30%, Over $136,750 but not over $297,300: $35,752.50 plus 35%, Over $297,300: $91,945 plus 38%. The tax rates for married individuals filing separate returns are as follows: Not over $6,000: 14%, Over $6,000 but not over $27,050: $840 plus 15%, Over $27,050 but not over $65,550: $3,997.50 plus 27%, Over $65,550 but not over $136,750: $14,362.50 plus 30%, Over $136,750 but not over $297,300: $35,752.50 plus 35%, Over $297,300: $91,945 plus 38%. Additionally, there is a phase-in of rate reductions for taxable years beginning after 2002, with reductions in tax rates imposed in 2002. In taxable years after 2002 and before 2007, tax rates were reduced by 1 percentage point in certain brackets, with additional reductions in later years. The Secretary was tasked with adjusting tables to reflect these changes. Inflation adjustments were made for determining rates in 2002, updating the years referenced in the tax code. In 2002, inflation adjustments were made to tax rates by updating the years referenced in the tax code. The Secretary was directed to make no adjustments to certain rate brackets for taxable years between 2002 and 2006, with different rules for later years. The tax code was updated in 2002 with inflation adjustments to tax rates. Amendments were made to various sections by replacing "1992" with "2000" in multiple provisions. The tax code was updated in 2002 with inflation adjustments to tax rates, including changes to various sections such as Section 42(h)(3)(H)(i)(II), Section 59(j)(2)(B), Section 63(c)(4)(B), and others. Sections 25A(h)(1)(A)(ii) and 25A(h)(2)(A)(ii) were also amended. The tax code was updated in 2002 with inflation adjustments to tax rates, including changes to various sections such as Section 42(h)(3)(H)(i)(II), Section 59(j)(2)(B), Section 63(c)(4)(B), and others. Sections 25A(h)(1)(A)(ii) and 25A(h)(2)(A)(ii) were also amended. Additional conforming amendments were made to sections such as 1(g)(7)(B)(ii)(II), 1(h), 531, and 541. The tax code was updated in 2002 with inflation adjustments to tax rates, including changes to various sections. Sections 531, 541, 3402, 3406, and others were amended to adjust percentages. The Secretary of the Treasury may prescribe alternative percentages to coordinate with the amendments. The tax code amendments in 2002 adjusted percentages in various sections, including section 3406(a)(1) changing from 31 percent to 25 percent. The Secretary of the Treasury can prescribe alternative percentages to align with the amendments. Effective dates for the amendments are after December 31, 2001, with specific withholding provisions applying to amounts paid after the same date. Repeal of phaseouts of deduction for personal exemptions and itemized deductions. Repeal of Phaseout of Personal Exemptions: Subsection (d) of section 151 is amended to remove the exemption amount phaseout. Technical amendments are made to adjust for inflation in taxable years after 1989. The dollar amount in paragraph (1) is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Section 68, which imposed an overall limitation on itemized deductions, is repealed along with technical amendments to related sections. The amendments in subparagraphs (C) and (D) involve striking certain clauses and items in section 773(a)(3) and the table of sections for part I of subchapter B of chapter 1. These changes will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
